awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Software Safety and Reliability: Research and Application
awd_abstract_narration:
As software safety and reliability are vital for safe and reliable operation of many systems and in reduction of catastrophic accidents, this Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) site at the University of Texas at Dallas provides cutting-edge research opportunities on these important topics to students, especially those from
underrepresented groups or universities with limited resources. After gaining skills in critical thinking, oral and written communication, problem solving, and research methods, students will be encouraged and well prepared for graduate education and research careers in science and technology. Their interactions with mentors and other participants will provide avenues to share ideas and results. Research connections will be established with students' home institutions to continue collaboration among multiple institutions in different geographical regions. REU website will publicize research articles, videos and slides of lectures and project presentations, and announcements for effective community outreach.

The subject of this research is software safety and reliability, with a focus on evaluating the strengths and weaknesses of existing methodologies and current practices for safety assurance and reliability prediction.  Issues to be studied include how the introduction of software safety and reliability requirements may affect the software lifecycle, and studying how software processes, methods and tool support should be adjusted. Further exploration will emphasize how safe software systems can be unreliable; how reliable software systems can be unsafe; and how to make software systems both safe and reliable. Our findings will be compiled to provide a comprehensive picture of how software safety and reliability can be achieved effectively and efficiently. An important aspect of this site is a close collaboration with industry. REU students will take field trips to industry sponsors, allowing them to speak directly with practitioners to better understand how software safety and reliability is applied to real-life applications. Workshops on technical writing and oral presentation will be held to improve students' proficiency in preparing and delivering technical reports. Seminars on ethics and professional responsibility will also be given to ensure REU students behave properly and respectfully.

por.por_cntn:
Software today plays a significant role in controlling the behavior of many systems, including service-oriented, mission-, and safety-critical applications. While safety ensures that a system does not end at any undesired state and causes unacceptable consequences, reliability is the probability of failure-free system operation for a given period of time in a specified environment. A hazard realized directly or indirectly through the software's operation can have catastrophic consequences, including property damage, financial loss, and serious injury or death. Thus, preventing such a disaster from occurring is of paramount importance.

An REU site at the University of Texas at Dallas (UTD) has been established where undergraduates, under close UTD faculty supervision, conduct research focusing on how to produce safe and reliable software more efficiently and effectively. There are various lectures at the beginning of the program to help students improve their competency in software safety and reliability before engaging in a specially designated project matching their interests and academic strengths. Workshops on technical writing and oral presentation are held to improve students' proficiency in preparing and delivering technical reports. Seminars on ethics and professional responsibility are also given to ensure REU students behave properly and respectfully. Field trips to our industry partners allow students to speak directly to practitioners and better understand how software safety and reliability are applied to real-life projects. Interactions between REU students, faculty mentors, and graduate students are emphasized. In addition to individual research, teamwork is encouraged. Follow-ups are conducted to prepare students for presentations at conferences and journal publications, as well as for graduate school applications. Each summer, a nation-wide call for participation is used to recruit ten students, at most five of which come from UTD or neighboring EPSCoR states. Priority is given to underrepresented minorities, women, persons with disabilities, and students from institutions with limited research resources. Each recruit has a background in Computer Science or Software Engineering.

The subject of this research is software safety and reliability with a focus on 1) evaluating the strengths and weaknesses of existing methodologies and current practices for safety assurance and reliability prediction; 2) investigating issues such as how the introduction of software safety and reliability requirements may affect the software lifecycle; and 3) studying how software processes, methods and tool support should be adjusted. Further exploration emphasizes how safe software systems can be unreliable; how reliable software systems can be unsafe; and how to make software systems both safe and reliable. A study on cost-effectiveness is conducted to answer questions such as "Does safe and reliable software cost more to produce?" Our findings provide a comprehensive picture of how software safety and reliability can be achieved effectively and efficiently. An extensive analysis of recent software-related accidents is performed so that the lessons learned can help prevent the same mistakes from recurring. This project closely collaborates with industry via an Advisory Board of several distinguished members.

As software safety and reliability are vital for the safe and reliable operation of many systems and the reduction of catastrophic accidents, this project provides cutting-edge research opportunities to students, especially those from underrepresented groups or universities with limited resources. After gaining skills in critical thinking, oral and written communication, problem solving, and research methods, our students are encouraged and well prepared for graduate education and research careers in science and technology. More than 60% of our REU alumni are either attending graduate schools or in the process of applying to graduate schools to pursue advanced degrees. Three are studying for their Doctoral degrees.
